title: Thesis Comic Sans
content:
Hello,

My name is Liesbeth Bonner and I am a graphic design master student at Sint-Lucas Ghent (Belgium). This year I have to write a thesis and I chose Comic Sans as my subject. I will mainly investigate the social aspects of the font: the reasons why so many people use it and so few designers like it. Offcourse I've never used Comic Sans, but for my thesis I am looking for great designers who did, with or without a twist of irony.

I've heard that Will Holder used it one time, but I can't find visual material on the web about it or in books. There's also Gorik Lindemans who made posters for the dance production Rosas (by Anne Teresa De Keersmaeker) and was inspired by the colours of an ad for Aldi (a cheap supermarket), I can't find this poster either.

Does anyone know where I can find these or are you a Comic Sans expert and do you know other designers who used it in a good way?

The tips would be very welcome,  
Thank you in advance,

Liesbeth

Why not combine hands-off perusal of vices, focusing your research on Comic Sans as used in online pornography?

Usages of Comic Sans abound but what is your thesis statement? You could gather some anecdotal information of funny or hideous uses of the typeface (tee hee, _look at this example_ kind of stuff,) but what are you trying to define? Finding examples will only ratify its usage in almost any context you want to refer to.

Some of its existence and prolific usage is because;  
It is owned by Microsoft,  
It is a default typeface on a couple of Microsoft programs,  
It is readable at small sizes for dialog on computer screens,  
It is free.

On the other hand, why is a typeface like **_Coop Forged_** by House Industries [view here,](http://web.archive.org/web/20130630064142/http:/www.houseind.com/index.php?page=showfont&id=12&subpage=viewfontspecimens) used so little? It is similar as maybe a dozen other comic-looking fonts. The argument my boil down to…it's not a default, not common and not free?

A defined thesis statement will focus your intention, or what you are really trying to discover.

Coop Forged is not used often because it isn't in every person on the planet's drop-down font menu. People specifically looking for hand-written fonts, more than likely, also want alternates. Coop Forged doesn't have alternates.
Well, now that you have edited your comment it looks as if I said something redundant. :^/

Sorry, had to change a word.  
You are right, no alternates. Still, some that only have access to a limited font library and use programs such as Word or Publisher will click the little buttons that have a **B** or an _I_ at the top of their tool bar for incorrect alternates such as **Bold** or _Italic_ anyway. Right now, the thesis argument is not stated. Anyone that owns a computer has free access to Comic Sans, therefore, someone is going to use it, poor choice or not.

Think of Comic Sans like this: Two people need to traverse across a large public park. Lets just assume that dogs are also allowed off leash to roam, play fetch or do their thing, there may be a few geese or other wildlife, etc. With those two people, one walks across while wearing utility boots, the other person, just in their bare feet while carrying their flip-flops. One person will be more concerned as to where they step while traveling to the other side while the other person possibly could care less. Both make it to the other side but one has more probability to really stink when they hop onto some public transit at the other side of the park. It is the same concept. It (Comic Sans,) is out there, it is possible to _step in_ and you may stink if you don't care how you get to the destination.

First of all, thanks for all the reactions.

second, I shall explain the sentence quoted a couple of times above:

'offcourse i've never used comic sans'.

I said that as a graphic design student who never dared to use it because it's such a difficult typeface to use in an art-environment. I can understand that comic sans is appropriate for applied graphic design, for example a hairdresser's shop (i picked this one because i've seen one with CS in the logo). At school during practice, it's easier to use typefaces that are allready proven to be good ones like Didot, Futura, Baskerville, Garamond, Univers, all the big names in typeworld. I think the only way to use comic sans (and in a design approved by my teachers :)) is in a design that refers to the commercial world and uses it's elements but without just copying them. There has to be an additional value. And layered meanings. Irony is not necessarily a part of it.  
This way of adopting elements of the 'low culture' can also be seen with other artists: Arne Sierens ( [http://www.arnesierens.be/](http://web.archive.org/web/20130630064142/http:/www.arnesierens.be/ "http://www.arnesierens.be/"))is a playwright who's stories are situated in for example fastfood restaurants, but his plays are considdered art because of the layers and the additional value. Also designer Walter Van Beirendonck ( [http://www.waltervanbeirendonck.com/](http://web.archive.org/web/20130630064142/http:/www.waltervanbeirendonck.com/ "http://www.waltervanbeirendonck.com/")) adopts elements of low culture and gives them a new meaning. It's in this way i would like to find some famous graphic designers who used comic sans, but i haven't found one yet. Maybe at the end of this year i myself can design something good with comic sans.

And about my thesis statement:

i'm still just researching and i'm following different paths at the same time. But i think i will mostly investigate the social aspects of the type: which people use it and for which purposes? which are the motives of the persons who use it? the things that are said by skinny\_tires are indeed some of the important reasons of the popularity of comic sans, but even if we just look at the fonts delivered with every computer, comic sans is still the most popular. Is it, as some organisations who researched dyslectia say, the best readable type? is it good for children who are just learning to read?

I hope you all get a nicer image of me and my thesis :) I haven't got the intention of turning my thesis in a freakshow to tell everyone how bad and ugly comic sans is. I want to investigate comic sans properly and if the solution is that comic sans a bad font is, then be it. But up to now, 'i believe in comic sans' (this is also my working titel of my masterproject)
